title: Tonic Tensor Tympanic Syndrome
chief_complaint: I have ringing in both ears, but the right one is considerably worse. I also feel pressure, sensitivity to sound, and a 'fluttering' sensation in my right ear.

problem_summary.onset: A few months prior to the appointment, following a hunting trip.
problem_summary.course: Tinnitus persisted longer than usual after the trip; symptoms worsened over time including new 'fluttering' sensation and increased anxiety.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Aural pressure, sound sensitivity (hyperacusis), minimal dull otalgia, mild dizziness/light-headedness, nausea, significant anxiety and depression.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient no longer wanted to return to school for the spring semester due to anxiety and depression.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking relief from tinnitus and anxiety; requested least invasive approach first.

encounters.setting: Private practice speech and hearing center

history.present_illness: Patient went on a hunting trip using hearing protection. Experienced tinnitus lasting longer than usual (previously only lasted a few hours). Right ear tinnitus worsened the morning after return. Developed aural pressure, sound sensitivity, and later a 'fluttering' sensation in the right ear.
history.otologic_history: History of hunting trips. Evaluated by urgent care (antibiotics/steroids prescribed with no effect). Evaluated by two ENT physicians (no anatomical abnormalities). Diagnosed with Tonic Tensor Tympanic Syndrome (TTTS) by ENT.
history.noise_exposure_history: Hunting trips; reported use of hearing protection devices.
history.medical_psych_history: MRI was normal. Reports significant anxiety and depression, which increased after receiving the TTTS diagnosis.
history.prior_management: Antibiotics and steroid shot (urgent care). ENT evaluation.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal hearing sensitivity from 250 to 8,000 Hz bilaterally.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs consistent with PTA. Word recognition scores excellent in quiet.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Normal in both ipsilateral and contralateral conditions.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.key_findings: QuickSIN administered at 60 dBA. Normal finding.

tests.name: Tinnitus Evaluation
tests.key_findings: Testing performed on the more bothersome ear (Right). Pitch match at 6kHz. Partial residual inhibition observed (slight decrease for 2-3 seconds).

numeric_results.Minimum_Masking_Level: 23 dB SL (38 dB HL) white noise

tests.name: Self-Report Scales
tests.key_findings: Tinnitus Reaction Questionnaire (TRQ) indicates catastrophic reaction.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing sensitivity bilaterally, excellent word recognition in quiet, and normal speech-in-noise ability. Middle ear function and acoustic reflexes are normal. However, the patient exhibits a 'catastrophic' reaction to tinnitus (TRQ score 88) and reports symptoms consistent with Tonic Tensor Tympanic Syndrome (TTTS), including fluttering and sound sensitivity, exacerbated by high levels of anxiety.
counseling_points: Reassure the patient that standard hearing tests show normal hearing sensitivity and no structural damage.
Explain the mechanism of Tonic Tensor Tympanic Syndrome (TTTS) as an involuntary muscle reflex often linked to anxiety and acoustic shock.
Discuss the strong link between tinnitus/TTTS and anxiety/depression, validating the patient's distress.
Recommend sound therapy (using a smartphone app or sound generator) to manage tinnitus and hyperacusis.
Provide a strong referral to a mental health professional (psychologist/therapist) to address the underlying anxiety and depression.
notes_for_actor: You are highly anxious and distressed. The previous diagnosis of 'Tonic Tensor Tympanic Syndrome' scared you because you didn't understand it.
You describe a 'fluttering' sensation in your right ear which is very disturbing.
You are hesitant about invasive treatments (like on-ear devices) and prefer to start with something simple like an app.
You have stopped going to school because of the distress.
